Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery krater (?) or bowl (?), large and thick-walled; remains of what appears to be a handle root at left edge of the fragment. Interior: reserved at top of sherd and second reserved band below; added red lines on glazed areas; exterior: above, small part of painted decoration, possibly tentacle of an octopus; below, black-figure octopus (body and part of two tentacles remaining). Clay orange-brown, relative fine and dense, but with some poorly sorted lime and little small mica; outside surface smoothed and slightly ruddle-coloured, with a plastic ridge.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The shape is suggestive of a large chalice.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 125, pl. XXXVIII, no. 351.8)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 232, no. 180)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1180)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4748 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
